conclusion: Consider the physics of the circuit and the behavior of the magnetic field as it weakens.
The circuit consists of a square wire frame, a capacitor, and a battery.
The side length of the square wire frame is L.
The capacitance of the capacitor is C.
The magnetic field weakens uniformly at a rate of change k.
The battery provides the potential difference across the capacitor.
The capacitor stores energy due to the potential difference.
The magnetic field affects the current in the wire frame.
The current in the wire frame can be found using the formula I = V/R.
V is the potential difference across the capacitor and R is the resistance of the wire frame.
The potential difference across the capacitor is V = Q/C.
The charge stored in the capacitor is Q = CV.
The potential difference across the capacitor is V = Q/C = CV/C = V.
Therefore, the current in the wire frame is I = V/R.
The induced EMF in the wire frame is given by the formula E = -dQ/dt.
E is the induced EMF and dQ/dt is the rate of change of the charge stored in the capacitor.
The rate of change of the charge stored in the capacitor is dQ/dt = CV * dV/dt.
The potential difference across the capacitor is V = Q/C, so dV/dt = dQ/dt * C/V.
Therefore, the rate of change of the charge stored in the capacitor is dQ/dt = CV^2 * dQ/dt.
Substituting into the formula for the induced EMF gives E = -CV^2 * dQ/dt.
Simplifying, we get E = -CV^3.
The current in the wire frame is I = V/R.
The magnitude of the induced electromotive force generated in the wire frame is E = -CV^3.
